Identify if the sequence defined by a_0=0, a_(n+1)=sqrt(6+a_n) is well-defined for all n≥0.
Determine whether the sequence is increasing, decreasing, or neither.
Check if the sequence is bounded above.
Apply the Monotone Convergence Theorem if the sequence is monotonic and bounded.
Assuming the sequence has a limit L, set up the equation L = sqrt(6 + L).
Solve the equation L = sqrt(6 + L) for L.
Verify the solution of the equation is a valid limit for the sequence by substituting back into the sequence definition.

Guess that the sequence converges to a limit L when n approaches infinity.
Assume convergence to determine the value of L, and find an equation related to L using the definition of the sequence.
Analyze whether the sequence is increasing, decreasing, or constant.
Check if the sequence is bounded.
Apply completeness of real numbers (or a suitable theorem regarding limits of recursive sequences) to determine if the limit indeed exists.
Calculate or verify the solution of the equation found in step 3 to confirm the limit.
Examine any special properties of the recursive sequence or additional criteria that could affect convergence.
